Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Jeffrey Harvey at the University of Chicago.

With the recent discovery of the long-sought Higgs boson, the theoretical framework underlying particle physics (the so-called "Standard Model" of particle physics) is now complete. However, there are still many important outstanding questions involving the fundamental structure of matter and energy and their interactions. These include what sorts of mathematical structures are needed to combine gravity and quantum mechanics, as well as the origin of dark matter and dark energy. String theory provides one possible framework to address these questions. Professor Harvey will pursue two independent lines of research aimed at addressing these questions. The first part of this project involves the study of "Little String Theory" - a theory that has some of the same good features of string theory but is easier to analyze. The second part of this project involves research in an area of pure mathematics that has close ties to techniques that grew out of string theory. This project thus advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. This project will also have significant broader impacts. The research will involve postdocs, graduate students and even at times undergraduate students, thus providing critical training for the next generation of physicists as they start research. The PI will also lecture at international schools and workshops and also participate in public outreach events in the Chicago area.

More technically, the PI will extend recent work on counting BPS states in Little String Theory to the study of more general backgrounds with N=2 supersymmetry. He will also continue his study of non-compact Conformal Field Theories and their connection to mock modular forms. This work has implications for the study of BPS states in supersymmetric field theories and to the study of string theory in a variety of physically interesting settings. A third component of this project involves the mathematics of some still-mysterious connections between sporadic groups and various types of modular and mock modular forms. In particular he will extend work currently in progress by extending techniques of Vertex Operator Algebras.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Number theory is the branch of mathematics that studies the properties of the integers and their generalizations. This sounds simple, but many problems that are simple to stateare difficult to answer. Many of the problems involve counting problems, like counting the number of ways one number can be written as a sum of smaller numbers. These kind ofcounting problems also arise in many places in physics. In string theory they arise by trying to understand what is known as the entropy of black holes which involves countingall states of the quantum system making up the black hole that have a fixed charge, mass and angular momentum.  In mathematics some of the counting functions appearingin number theory have also turned out to be connected with what are known as finite groups. Roughly speaking finite groups are symmetries of  various kinds of mathematicalobjects. One of the most remarkable of these groups is called the Monster group. It is the largest of what are known as sporadic groups and it is connected with a solution to string theory. This connection between groups and string theory is known as moonshine. This project developed and extended these moonshine connections in new directions.  This projectalso borrowed some tools from number theory and used them to find new connections between what are known as two-dimensional conformal field theories or CFTs for short. CFTsgovern solutions to string theory but also have wider applications. For example they can be used to describe some of the physical degrees of freedom that govern the behavior ofcertain materials in large magnetic fields (Quantum Hall Systems). Thus the results of this project may also be eventually used to better understand the physics of these kindsof materials. 
This project also had broader impacts for society as a whole in that it helped to train two graduate students and two post-doctoral associates in physics and this helps toproduce a scientifically literate workforce. New developments in science and math are also of interest to the general public and the work done here was presented to the generalpublic in several ways including a public lecture at the Simons Foundation in New York City and a presentation to high school physics students in Glenwood Springs, Colorado.
